Wonderswan Color.name: Wonderswan Color
Wonderswan Color.description: Powered by a 16-bit central processing unit, it took advantage of a low price point and long battery life in comparison to its competition

Scumm VM.name: Scumm VM
Scumm VM.description: Play the classic 'Point and Click' graphic adventure games from different platforms and systems like MS-DOS, C64, Apple II, or PC

Sega Genesis CD.name: Sega Genesis CD
Sega Genesis CD.description: CD-ROM add-on to the Genesis, it launched many FMV games, including the infamous Night Trap, which led to the creation of the ESRB

Sega Genesis 32x.name: Sega Genesis 32x
Sega Genesis 32x.description: Designed to expand the power of the Genesis and serve as a transitional console into the 32-bit era until the release of the Sega Saturn

NEC PC-88.name: NEC PC-88
NEC PC-88.description: Lineup of Japanese 16-bit and 32-bit personal computers manufactured by NEC from 1982 to 2000

Sega MegaCD.name: Sega MegaCD
Sega MegaCD.description: CD-ROM add-on to the Megadrive, it launched many FMV games, including the infamous Night Trap, which led to the creation of the ESRB

Sega Megadrive.name: Sega Megadrive
Sega Megadrive.description: Sega's third console and the successor to the Master System. First released as the Mega Drive in Japan

SuperGrafx.name: SuperGrafx
SuperGrafx.description: The SuperGrafx is an upgraded version of the PC Engine. Only six retail games were produced which took advantage of the improved hardware

PC-Engine CD.name: PC-Engine CD
PC-Engine CD.description: Add-on attachment for the PC Engine. The add-on allows core versions of the console to play PC Engine games in CD-ROM format

Sega Naomi.name: Sega Naomi
Sega Naomi.description: A development of the Dreamcast home game console, the NAOMI and Dreamcast share the same hardware components.

Sony Playstation 2.name: Sony Playstation 2
Sony Playstation 2.description: The PlayStation 2 is the best-selling video game console of all time, selling over 155 million units.

PC-Engine.name: PC-Engine
PC-Engine.description: Originally intended to compete with the NES, it ended up competing with the Sega Genesis, and later on the Super Nintendo

PC-Engine CD.name: PC-Engine CD
PC-Engine CD.description: Add-on attachment for the PC Engine. The add-on allows core versions of the console to play PC Engine games in CD-ROM format

NEC PC-98.name: NEC PC-98
NEC PC-98.description: Lineup of Japanese 16-bit and 32-bit personal computers manufactured by NEC from 1982 to 2000

Neo Geo CD.name: Neo Geo CD
Neo Geo CD.description: Originally launched as the MVS coin-operated arcade machine. It was ranked 19th out of 25 best video game consoles of all time

Sony Playstation 3.name: Sony Playstation 3
Sony Playstation 3.description: The PlayStation 3 (PS3) is a home video game console developed by Sony Computer Entertainment. The successor to the PlayStation 2, it is part of the PlayStation brand of consoles.

MSX.name: MSX
MSX.description: MSX is a standardized home computer architecture, conceived as an attempt to create unified standards among various hardware makers

MSX 2.name: MSX 2
MSX 2.description: MSX2 is a standardized home computer architecture, conceived as an attempt to create unified standards among various hardware makers

MSX 2.name: MSX 2
MSX 2.description: MSX2 is a standardized home computer architecture, conceived as an attempt to create unified standards among various hardware makers

Nintendo 64.name: Nintendo 64
Nintendo 64.description: The N64 was the last major home console to use the cartridge as its primary storage format until Nintendo's seventh console, the Nintendo Switch

Neo Geo Pocket Color.name: Neo Geo Pocket Color
Neo Geo Pocket Color.description: The Neo Geo Pocket Color is the successor to SNK's monochrome Neo Geo Pocket, with the Color being fully backward compatible

Neo Geo CD.name: Neo Geo CD
Neo Geo CD.description: Originally launched as the MVS coin-operated arcade machine. It was ranked 19th out of 25 best video game consoles of all time

Sega Mega 32x.name: Sega Mega 32x
Sega Mega 32x.description: Designed to expand the power of the Megadrive and serve as a transitional console into the 32-bit era until the release of the Sega Saturn

Pico 8.name: Pico 8
Pico 8.description: PICO-8 is a virtual machine and game engine created by Lexaloffle Games.

n3ds.name: Nintendo 3DS
n3ds.description: The handheld's most prominent feature is its ability to display stereoscopic 3D effects without the use of 3D glasses or additional accessories.

segacd.name: Sega SegaCD
segacd.description: CD-ROM add-on to the Megadrive, it launched many FMV games, including the infamous Night Trap, which led to the creation of the ESRB

3DO.name: 3DO
3DO.description: The 3DO Interactive Multiplayer (often called simply the 3DO), is a home video game console platform developed by The 3DO Company

NintendoSwitch.name: Nintendo Switch
NintendoSwitch.description: The console itself is a tablet that can either be docked for use as a home console or used as a portable device, making it a hybrid console.

FinalBurnNeo.name: Final Burn Neo
FinalBurnNeo.description: Coin-operated entertainment machines. The golden age is defined as a period between the late 1970s and ending in the mid-1980s

Nintendo3DS.name: Nintendo 3DS
Nintendo3DS.description: The handheld's most prominent feature is its ability to display stereoscopic 3D effects without the use of 3D glasses or additional accessories, and offers new features such as the StreetPass and SpotPass tag modes, powered by Nintendo Network; augmented reality using its 3D cameras; and Virtual Console

SinclairZXSpectrum.name: Sinclair ZX Spectrum
SinclairZXSpectrum.description: The Spectrum was among the first mainstream-audience home computers in the UK, similar in significance to the Commodore 64 in the USA

FamicomDiskSystem.name: Famicom Disk System
FamicomDiskSystem.description: The Family Computer is a peripheral for Nintendo's Family Computer home video game console, released only in Japan

MAME.name: M.A.M.E.
MAME.description: Coin-operated entertainment machines. The golden age is defined as a period between the late 1970s and ending in the mid-1980s

LightgunGenre.name: Lightgun Genre
LightgunGenre.description: Light gun shooter, is a shooter video game genre in which the primary design element is aiming and shooting with a gun-shaped controller

FightingGenre.name: Fighting Genre
FightingGenre.description: In a fighting game, the player engages in close combat with an AI or player-controlled opponent

gba.name: GameBoy Advance
gba.description: Successor to the Game Boy Color. Market competitors at the time were the Neo Geo Pocket Color, Wonder Swan, GP32 and the N-Gage

FinalBurnAlpha.name: Final Burn Alpha
FinalBurnAlpha.description: Coin-operated entertainment machines. The golden age is defined as a period between the late 1970s and ending in the mid-1980s

NintendoGameCube.name: Nintendo GameCube
NintendoGameCube.description: The Nintendo GameCube is the successor to the Nintendo 64 and is the first Nintendo console to use optical discs as its primary storage medium

SegaGameGear.name: Sega GameGear
SegaGameGear.description: The Game Gear shares much of its hardware with the Master System and is able to play its own titles as well as those of the Master System

gbc.name: GameBoy Color
gbc.description: The Game Boy Color features a color screen. It is slightly thicker and taller and features a slightly smaller screen than the Game Boy Pocket

SegaMasterSystem.name: Sega Master System
SegaMasterSystem.description: Succeeding the SG-1000, the Master System was released as a direct competitor to the Nintendo Entertainment System (NES)

FinalBurnNeo.name: Final Burn Neo
FinalBurnNeo.description: Coin-operated entertainment machines. The golden age is defined as a period between the late 1970s and ending in the mid-1980s

GameAndWatch.name: Game & Watch
GameAndWatch.description: Line of handheld electronic games produced by Nintendo from 1980 to 1991. Created by game designer Gunpei Yokoi

Intellivision.name: Intellivision
Intellivision.description: The Intellivision is a home video game console released by Mattel Electronics, and was in direct competition with the Atari 2600

gb.name: Nintendo GameBoy
gb.description: Nintendo's second handheld system following the Game & Watch series. It mainly competed with Game Gear and Lynx

Commodore64.name: Commodore 64
Commodore64.description: The C64 is listed in the Guinness World Records as the highest-selling single computer model of all time.

3d0.name: 3DO
3d0.description: The 3DO Interactive Multiplayer (often called simply the 3DO), is a home video game console platform developed by The 3DO Company

snes.name: Super Nintendo
snes.description: Nintendo's second home console introduced advanced graphics and sound capabilities compared with other systems at the time

genesis.name: Sega Genesis
genesis.description: Sega's third console and the successor to the Master System. Released in North America as the Genesis

Commodore16.name: COMMODORE 16
Commodore16.description: Home computer made by Commodore International, intended to be an entry-level computer to replace the VIC-20

SegaDreamcast.name: Sega Dreamcast
SegaDreamcast.description: The Dreamcast was Sega's final home console, marking the end of the company's 18 years in the console market

TurboGrafxCD.name: TurboGrafx CD
TurboGrafxCD.description: Add-on attachment for the TurboGrafx-16. The add-on allows core versions of the console to play TurboGrafx-16 games in CD-ROM format

TurboGrafx16.name: TurboGrafx-16
TurboGrafx16.description: Originally intended to compete with the NES, it ended up competing with the Sega Genesis, and later on the Super Nintendo

Microsoft Xbox.name: Microsoft Xbox
Microsoft Xbox.description: The Xbox is a home video game console and the first installment in the Xbox series of video game consoles manufactured by Microsoft. It was released as Microsoft's first foray into the gaming console market.

COCO TRS-80.name: COCO TRS-80
COCO TRS-80.description: Sold by Tandy through their RadioShack stores. It is one of the earliest mass-produced home computers.

Coleco Vision.name: Coleco Vision
Coleco Vision.description: The ColecoVision offered a closer experience to more powerful arcade game systems compared to competitors such as the Atari 2600.

Vectrex.name: Vectrex
Vectrex.description: Vector display based home video game console that was developed by Western Technologies Smith Engineering.

CAPCOM SYSTEM I.name: CAPCOM SYSTEM I
CAPCOM SYSTEM I.description: The CPS is an arcade system board developed by Capcom that ran game software stored on removable ROM cartridges.

COMMODORE VIC-20.name: COMMODORE VIC-20
COMMODORE VIC-20.description: The VIC-20 was the first computer of any description to sell one million units.

CAPCOM SYSTEM II.name: CAPCOM SYSTEM II
CAPCOM SYSTEM II.description: Arcade board that Capcom first used for Super Street Fighter II. It was the successor to their previous CPS.

Nintendo VirtualBoy.name: Nintendo VirtualBoy
Nintendo VirtualBoy.description: It was marketed as the first console capable of displaying stereoscopic 3D graphics using a parallax effect to create the illusion of depth.

Nintendo Wii.name: Nintendo Wii
Nintendo Wii.description: The Wii introduced the Wii Remote controller, which can be used as a handheld pointing device and detects movement in three dimensions.

CAPCOM SYSTEM III.name: CAPCOM SYSTEM III
CAPCOM SYSTEM III.description: The last proprietary system board Capcom would produce before moving on to the Dreamcast-based Naomi platform.

Daphne.name: Daphne
Daphne.description: Converged device and home video game console capable of playing Laserdiscs, Compact Discs, console games, and LD-G karaoke discs.

Custom Collection.name: Custom Collection
Custom Collection.description: Access and quickly play games you have added to your custom collections.

Nintendo WiiU.name: Nintendo WiiU
Nintendo WiiU.description: Successor to the Wii and the first eighth-gen video game console, as it competed with Microsoft's Xbox One and Sony's PS4.

Wonderswan.name: Wonderswan
Wonderswan.description: Powered by a 16-bit central processing unit, it took advantage of a low price point and long battery life in comparison to its competition.

Shoot 'em Up Genre.name: Shoot 'em Up Genre
Shoot 'em Up Genre.description: In a shoot 'em up, the player shoots large numbers of enemies while dodging obstacles, often in a spacecraft or aircraft.

X68000.name: X68000
X68000.description: The X68000 is a home computer, sold only in Japan. In terms of hardware, the X68K was very similar to arcade machines of the time.

Atari 7800.name: Atari 7800
Atari 7800.description: Almost fully backward-compatible with the Atari 2600, the 7800 was the first console to have backward compatibility without the use of additional modules.

Super Famicom.name: Super Famicom
Super Famicom.description: Nintendo's second home console introduced advanced graphics and sound capabilities compared with other systems at the time.

Amstrad CPC.name: Amstrad CPC
Amstrad CPC.description: The Amstrad CPC is a series of 8-bit home computers. The CPC series was pitched against other home computers and enjoyed a strong supply of game software.

Amiga.name: Amiga
Amiga.description: The original model was part of a wave of 16 and 32 bit computers that featured 256KB or more of RAM, mouse-based GUIs, and improved graphics & audio.

Amiga CD32.name: Amiga CD32
Amiga CD32.description: The original model was part of a wave of 16 and 32 bit computers that featured 256KB or more of RAM, mouse-based GUIs, and improved graphics & audio.

Amiga 1200.name: Amiga 1200
Amiga 1200.description: The CD32 is part of a family of Amiga computers and other hardware. It uses CD-ROM as its storage medium. It was based on Commodore's Advanced Graphics Architecture chipset, and is of similar specification to the Amiga 1200 personal computer.

Amiga 600.name: Amiga 600
Amiga 600.description: The CD32 is part of a family of Amiga computers and other hardware. It uses CD-ROM as its storage medium. It was based on Commodore's Advanced Graphics Architecture chipset, and is of similar specification to the Amiga 1200 personal computer.

MS-DOS.name: MS-DOS
MS-DOS.description: MS-DOS is an operating system for x86-based personal computers mostly developed by Microsoft.

Atari 5200.name: Atari 5200
Atari 5200.description: Home video game console that was introduced as a higher-end complementary console for the popular Atari 2600.

Apple ][.name: Apple ][
Apple ][.description: One of the first highly successful mass-produced microcomputer products, designed primarily by Steve Wozniak.

Sega Genesis 32x.name: Sega Genesis 32x
Sega Genesis 32x.description: Designed to expand the power of the Genesis and serve as a transitional console into the 32-bit era until the release of the Sega Saturn.

Atari 2600.name: Atari 2600
Atari 2600.description: The Atari 2600 is credited with popularizing the use of microprocessor-based hardware and ROM cartridges containing game code.

Sega SG-1000.name: Sega SG-1000
Sega SG-1000.description: Sega's first entry into the home video game hardware business provided the basis for the more successful Master System.

Atari 800.name: Atari 800
Atari 800.description: The Atari 8-bit family is a series of 8-bit home computers. All of the machines in the family are technically similar and differ primarily in packaging.

Adventure Genre.name: Adventure Genre
Adventure Genre.description: In an adventure game the player follows an interactive story, driven by exploration and puzzle-solving.

psvita.name: psvita
psvita.description: The Vita's design was intended to meld the experience of big-budget, dedicated video game platforms with the then up-and-coming trend of mobile gaming.

Action Genre.name: Action Genre
Action Genre.description: An action game emphasizes physical challenges, including hand–eye coordination and reaction-time.

Atari Jaguar CD.name: Atari Jaguar CD
Atari Jaguar CD.description: Sixth and last programmable console to be developed under the Atari brand, Atari marketed the Jaguar as being the first 64-bit video game console.

Atari Jaguar.name: Atari Jaguar
Atari Jaguar.description: Sixth and last programmable console to be developed under the Atari brand, Atari marketed the Jaguar as being the first 64-bit video game console.

Atari ST.name: Atari ST
Atari ST.description: The Atari ST is a line of home computers from Atari Corporation and the successor to the Atari 8-bit family.

Atari Lynx.name: Atari Lynx
Atari Lynx.description: The Lynx was the world's first handheld electronic game with a color LCD and was also notable for its advanced graphics and ambidextrous layout.

Atomiswave.name: Atomiswave
Atomiswave.description: Custom arcade system board and cabinet from Sammy Corporation. It is based on Sega's Dreamcast system board.

Sports Genre.name: Sports Genre
Sports Genre.description: Most sports have been recreated with a game, including team sports, track and field, extreme sports and combat sports.

All Games.name: All Games
All Games.description: Access and quickly play every single game across the entire library.

Valve Steam.name: Valve Steam
Valve Steam.description: Developed by Valve Corporation, Steam offers digital rights management, multiplayer gaming, video streaming and social networking services.

psp.name: Sony Playstation Portable
psp.description: Sony's first handheld, it was also the first real competition to Nintendo handhelds since the Game Gear.

psx.name: Sony Playstation
psx.description: The Sony PlayStation primarily competed with the Nintendo 64 and the Sega Saturn as part of the fifth generation of video game consoles.

Sega Genesis 32x.name: Sega Genesis 32x
Sega Genesis 32x.description: Designed to expand the power of the Genesis and serve as a transitional console into the 32-bit era until the release of the Sega Saturn.

Sega Saturn.name: Sega Saturn
Sega Saturn.description: Fifth generation home video game console developed by Sega and successor to the successful Sega Genesis.

Sega Saturn (Sega Japan).name: Sega Saturn
Sega Saturn (Sega Japan).description: Fifth generation home video game console developed by Sega and successor to the successful Sega Genesis.

Microsoft Xbox 360.name: Microsoft Xbox 360
Microsoft Xbox 360.description: The Xbox 360 is a home video game console developed by Microsoft. As the successor to the original Xbox, it is the second console in the Xbox series.
